bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 167, Number 197 (Friday, November 12, 2021)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. JACKSON:H.R. 5955.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I Section 8 of the United States Constitution[Page H6247]

item.title: To extend the pilot program on partnership agreements to construct new facilities for the Department of Veterans Affairs, and for other purposes.

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Health.

item.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations.
Referred to the House Committee on Veterans' Affairs.

summary.text: This bill requires the Department of Veterans Affairs to report on the pilot program under which it may accept donations of real property or facilities from specified entities (e.g., a state or local authority).

bill.title: To direct the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to submit to Congress reports on the pilot program on acceptance by the Department of Veterans Affairs of donated facilities and related improvements.

item.title: To direct the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to submit to Congress reports on the pilot program on acceptance by the Department of Veterans Affairs of donated facilities and related improvements.
To direct the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to submit to Congress reports on the pilot program on acceptance by the Department of Veterans Affairs of donated facilities and related improvements.

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
